body: Avoid GPU->CPU transfer by allocating the output on the GPU using iobinding and then time the run call.

Will it force device synchronization, i.e. would GPU->GPU copy be synchronous?

E.g. if you do the same in PyTorch even with pre-allocated output, the measurements may not be correct, because of async CUDA execution

That's why I was interested how to force CUDA synchronization in user code?

Have you taken a look at this:

https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/blob/8d737f977056444a307f1b7f0bcd402fba62d790/onnxruntime/test/python/onnxruntime_test_python_iobinding.py#L69

It pretty much does what you are asking for. It pre-allocates an output "offline" and binds it as an output so that ORT can write results to it. Notice that there is no `Sync()` call here because calling Run...() itself ensure that the compute stream has synced before returning back to the user. The kernels run asynchronously but at the end, there is a CUDA compute stream sync and this should ensure that the results in your buffer are correct.

I had looked at this, but this one does explicit copy to the CPU `io_binding.copy_outputs_to_cpu()[0]`, so this has been confusing me.

It was not clear from the docs that after GPU->GPU Run, the Sync happens before returning to the user.

rename.from: How to force CUDA stream synchronization?
rename.to: Explain in the docs that run() or run_with_binding() always synchronizes the CUDA stream prior to returning control

body: I changed the issue name to reflect this confusion

We do the `copy_outputs_to_cpu()` just to bring the results to cpu to complete the test validation. You are free to not call this method at all. There is a comment in the code before the `copy_outputs_...()` call to suggest this.

rename.from: Explain in the docs that run() or run_with_binding() always synchronizes the CUDA stream prior to returning control
rename.to: Explain in the docs that run() or run_with_binding() always synchronizes the CUDA stream prior to returning control (or an explicit note about proper benchmarking ONNX ops versus PyTorch ops)
